bibl.title: Translation [from Spanish] and transcription of an article from Diario de la Marina, April 19, 1947

div1.p: This Cuban newspaper article describes the visit of Cuban officials and Moran to the Camp Lazear site. Building No. 1 has been named a national monument.

div1.head: Translation [from Spanish] and transcription of an article from Diario de la Marina, April 19, 1947
div1.p:
THE SHACK WHERE DOCTOR FINLAY WORKED WAS VISITED BY THE
MINISTER OF HEALTH AND OTHER HEALTH OFFICIALS
$10,000 WAS DONATED

As the DIARIO DE LA MARINA informed, the Minister of Health,
Doctor Jose R. Andreu, the Director of Health, Doctor Pedro Nogueira,
Professor Rodolfo Perez de los Reyes, and Mr. John J. Moran, the only
survivor of the American Commission which proved Finlay's theory about
a transmission of yellow fever from man to man by a mosquito, visited
this morning the shack in Quemados de Marianao. This shack was de-
clared by the group of ministers as a National monument--also the house
and the farm--called San Jose--where Doctor Carlos J. Finlay with the
cooperation of members of the Jesuits made the first experiments in
his great discovery.

The Cabrera family lives in this farm now and they were very
kind to the visitors, allowing them to examine the places where the
Jesuits made the experiments knowing that many priests offered their
free help to Doctor Finlay and offered themselves as human guinea pigs
for the good of humanity. Doctor Andreu said that a commenorative
plaque would be placed here.

Mr. Moran showed in this shack deteriorated by weather and
the years the sites where Doctor Finlay and the American Commission,
presided by Doctor Reed who informed Major Gorgas, used to work about
yellow fever being endemic in Cuba for more than 200 years.

Doctor Perez de los Reyes informed that the Mayo Clinic was
donating the amount of $10,000 for the reconstruction and conserva-
tion of this shack where the American Commission, presided by Doctor
Reed and helped by Doctor Finlay, worked.
